title: 109_s3559
content: The Act titled "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" enhances penalties for fraud related to major disaster or emergency benefits. The Act "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" amends Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code to address fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. It includes penalties for falsifying information or making fraudulent statements related to benefits authorized in connection with disaster declarations or emergency procurement. The Act "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" imposes penalties for fraud related to emergency or disaster benefits provided by the United States government. Penalties include fines and imprisonment for up to 30 years for individuals involved in fraudulent activities. The term "benefit" in this context refers to any form of value provided by the government or other entities. The Act "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" imposes penalties for fraud related to emergency or disaster benefits provided by the United States government, State, or local entities. The term "benefit" refers to any form of value provided. SEC. 3 amends Section 1343 of title 18, United States Code, to increase criminal penalties for wire fraud related to presidentially declared disasters or emergencies. SEC. 4 amends Section 1341 to increase penalties for mail fraud in the same context. SEC. 5 directs the Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to increase penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to major disaster or emergency declarations. They must also submit an explanation of their actions and policy recommendations to Congress. The Commission must ensure that sentencing guidelines reflect the seriousness of these offenses. The United States Sentencing Commission is mandated to enhance penalties for fraud or theft offenses linked to major disaster or emergency declarations. They must promptly implement the guidelines or amendments within 30 days of the enactment of the Act, ensuring consistency with other directives and guidelines, considering aggravating or mitigating circumstances, and conforming changes to sentencing guidelines. The guidelines must align with the purposes of sentencing as outlined in the law.
